text:
I have made this mistake several times, and everyone that I have ever helped get set 
up on log4j has made it.  If your file from -Dlog4j.configuration=<file> is not in your 
classpath, then it won't be found.  Also, the first file named <file> in your classpath is 
the one that is found.

So, the question is:

Why is log4j finding the wrong configuration file or not finding my configuration file 
when I use -Dlog4j.configuration=<file>?

Answer:
The log4j.configuration property prompts log4j to search in your classpath for the file 
you give as the property value.  If you don't put the directory containing your 
configuration file in your classpath (often you want to use '.', your current working 
directory, so just prepend . to your classpath), then log4j won't find the file.  Also, 
log4j searches your classpath in order for the file name listed.  So if you have 
another file of the same name lurking out there somewhere in your classpath, log4j 
may not be using the configuration file you think it should be using.
